column4: you could check that you dont have anything unusual in /etc/X11
what should i be looking for?
what kind of video card do you have?
I've already ran sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg-video-intel
make sure you don't have an Xorg.conf in /etc/x11 thats the only real suggestion i can give
thats unusual, but since its failsafe i wouldn't worry

you might test to see if this happens for any other user. you could create a throwaway account and try the same there. if nothing bad happens then it might be in your .* files otherwise it must be /etc
it works fine under other user
since i cant find it anywhere im going to guess it is in gconf you might look in there
what would i be looking for in .gonf
use gconf-editor. otherwise just be looking for anything that might be related to xrandr
so just delete it and restart?
sure... you will lose any customization you made to your gnome apps but you can just removeit
like my favorites programs and stuff?
just whatever customizations are a in it. like background selection, theme selection, font selection etc
